remixed_from.title: LED Light Bar for MakerGear M2

title: Another MakerGear M2 LED Light Bar

description.text:
This one might be easier to print for those having trouble printing the arched one. This has room for 8 LEDs, and is held in place by four of the screws holding the X-axis rail in place. (The holes for the nuts are deeply recessed, so you don't need longer screws.) Enjoy!
Dale

I sliced this with Simplify3D Creator using auto support generation with 0.5 mm grid and 0.5 mm separation to get supports for the screw holes that were easy to break out.  
I wired two series strings of 4 LEDs each, with a 240 ohm 1/2 watt resistor in series with each string (gives about 20 mA per string), and powered by the 19V supply.  I just paralleled the wires onto the 4-pin block powering the RAMBo board.  No batteries needed.  
I printed this in black PLA, so it looks like it came with my black M2.

comments.text: Couple issues I ran into with this design. First, the nuts aren't recessed enough...so unless you're forcefully, and I mean forcefully pushing them up while simultaneously screwing the bolts in from the top, they won't connect. Second...the LED's themselves need to be recessed, and even then, the clearance for the v4 hotend may not be enough. Something to be aware of since the LEDs not extending past the bottom of the housing isn't mentioned in the design. I tried to lower the v4, and reset z zero so I wouldn't have wasted all my time on the light strip.
comments.author: jdlev

This is a two-piece model rocket where the nose threads onto the base.

First we extruded a cylinder for the base. Then we hollowed it out. Then we added fins to the base. Next we threaded the base so the nose could screw on. Then designed and extruded the rocket's nose. We threaded the bottom so it screwed onto the base. Finally we assembled these parts into the finished model rocket.

Project: Model Rocket Objectives: FURTHER SKILLS OF AUTO CAD AND INVENTOR. GET A BETTER IDEA OF THE SCIENTIFIC METHOD AND PROCESS
AUDIENCES: BEGINNERS OR INTERMEDIATE AT HIGHSCHOOL LEVEL
PREPARATION: HAVE HAD A N ENTRY LEVEL COURSE TO AUTO CAD OR INVENTOR OR SOME SORT OF ON COMPUTER DRAFTING ABLE TO CREATE ANY SHAPE OR OBJECT DESIRED WITH LITTLE HELP
STEPS: SEE SUMMARY
RESULTS: PERFECTION

title: Luna Park Side Tower- Coney Island Play Set

description.text:
This is another fantasy architecture model based on historic Coney Island buildings. The original Luna Park was created in 1903 by Frederic Thompson. Thompson was a rebel who was kicked out the Beaux Arts Academy in Paris. The original postmodern architect, He created Luna Park- a fantasy landscape in Coney Island, comprised of dozens of minarets and towers, combining architectural styles ranging from far eastern to renaissance. At night, the landscape was transformed into an electric fantasy lit by hundreds of thousands of lights. Please note I don't yet have a 3D printer myself and have not yet tried printing this. If anyone prints it, please post some photos! Update: 7/1/2012
I've added successfully printed files created by Jason Batukis and the MakerBot Botfarm for the 2012 Mermaid Parade trophies. Thanks!

Print the parts and glue them together. I suggest white or clear plastic, but its your call. Make two of these towers and set them on either side of a print of the Electric Tower model: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13046 Enjoy!

description.text: Box made to hold a pocket bible for my pastor.  This was my first try at creating a hinged box. Used a 1/8" x 1" roll pin for the hinge pin.  Design was based on the masonic chaplain's jewel.

Postanowiłem tym razem zająć się systemem zobrazowania przesyłanego obrazu z bezzałogowca na ziemię. Oczywiście możliwości jest wiele począwszy od monitora 5', 7' lub przy pomocy gogli. Na rynku jest kilka firm, które mają w swojej ofercie takie wizjery, jednak ich cena potrafi przetrzepać kieszeń młodego majsterkowicza hobbysty. Podczas przeszukiwania internetu trafiłem na wizjery w cenie 76 dolarów. Obraz jaki jest przez nie oferowany to 432 x 240 przy 24- bit głębi kolorów. Oczywiście poprzez układ soczewek powstaje nam obraz pozorny w wielkości 52 cali oddalony pozornie o 2 m i w proporcjach 4:3.
Model tych gogli to VG260. Oczywiście posiadają w swoim zestawie wyprowadzenie dźwięku i obrazu. Zasilane są ze źródła zewnętrznego 5V lub z baterii wewnętrznej 3,7V pozwalającej na pracę ciągło w wymiarze 3 godzin. Pomyślałem, że jest to już wystarczająca baza do mojego projektu. W rogramie darmowym DesignSpark Mechanical zaprojektowałem obudowę przyszłych gogli. Projekt wydrukowałem na drukarce HARBOT w PLA firmy Wolfix, jako cienkościenny korpus. Mogłem to uzyskać dzięki dyszy 0,3 mm oraz dobrej jakości filamentu. Po wydrukowaniu zabrałem się za pokrycie wszystkiego warstwą włókna carbonowego przesączonego żywicą epoksydową. Zamontowanie pasków i przyklejenie paska pianki podnoszącej komfort przy noszeniu było kwestią już tylko chwili. Do mocowania odbiornika sygnału i jego zasilania zastosowałem naramienny uchwyt telefoniczny. Jako, że posiadam wadę wzroku, to zaprojektowałem nasadki na gogle, w które można montować dowolne szkła korekcyjne. Oczywiście szkła musiałem zamówić w zakładzie optycznym, jednak uprzejmości optyka nie była to jakaś wygórowana cena. description.text:
I was given some Canadian Dare Ultimate Maple Leaf crème filled cookies as a Christmas present from my sister who lives in Canada (I live in the UK). And I loved them so much I decided to make my own. I wanted to make the cookies look the part so designed and 3D printed my very own maple leaf cookie cutter complete with Dare logo stamp to give it that authentic look.
I found a recipe for cookies (or biscuits as we call them here), and the crème fondant filling, then changed the recipe to include maple syrup. I then made the cookie dough, and used my newly 3D printed parts to cut and stamp them the same as the Canadian cookies.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes: Small amount of support required in the hole where the handle will be glued. Slightly different handle pictured than included in the files, it's a nicer design and fits the hole as mentioned above better.

Ingredients Biscuit Recipe 225 g plain flour
½ tsp baking powder
50 g custard powder
50 g icing sugar
175 g butter, chilled and diced
2 tbsp milk
2 tbsp maple syrup Filling Recipe 75 g butter, soft
50 g icing sugar
1 tbsp custard powder Biscuit method Sift the dry ingredients together into a large bowl, then add the cubed butter and rub the mixture together between your thumbs and finger tips. Once it is mixed in and is the consistency of wet sand, make a well in the middle and add in the milk and maple syrup. Then use a butter knife to cut the liquid into the mixture, once it starts to thicken roll the knife around and it will come together. Chill for 30 minutes minimum then roll out on a floured surface to about 6mm, place on a baking sheet and bake for 11-15 minutes at about 180° in a fan oven. Crème fondant filling method Make sure the butter is softened, then just cream together with the icing sugar a bit at a time. Make a dry mixture by adding more icing sugar, then when it's solid add the maple syrup to soften it up again. You'll want a fairly solid filling to hold the two halves of the sandwich biscuit together.

title: Rocker Blotter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I really like fountain pens and the huge variety of inks, nibs, styles, and the things you can do with them that you can't do with an ordinary ballpoint/felt pen. There are many advantages to using a fountain pen, and some disadvantages. One of them is, if the ink is too wet you can smear or cause transferring onto reverse sheets of paper. The rocker blotter is a traditional device used to hold blotting paper and let's you easily pick up the excess ink from your writing without the smearing. You don't slide the paper across the writing (which would smear), you place the edge down and rock it across. This video gives a pretty good overview, and that's where I picked up my strips of blotting paper (no affiliation): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JGsOU1EJumc
Files removed per overreaching Terms of Service and in protest of Makerbot's anti-open source stances. For files, please go to http://mazaw.github.com/githubiverse-Rocker-Blotter/

description.text: This is modeled after the Derelict Lightsaber from SW:TOR. I normally try to make my parts print without support, but it just wasn't possible with this one. I had to use supports for the Emitter_head_bottom, and the Emitter_ring. Also, while the emitter, body, grip, and pummel connect with either their own threading or the couplers from my Lightsaber Creation Kit (included here as well), the switch, studs, buttons, ring all have to be glued into place. I also over twisted the emitter head to get the two parts to aline properly. Many parts may need some sanding to fit right. The Blade (which I am including) is a W.I.P. The couplers for it don't work with their threads after printed (might work at 100 microns) so I had to sand them down and force them in, then attack the next section and fuse them together. The blade does screw in and out of the emitter so you can attach and remove it as you want. The one in my picture is 35 inches long, which means 5 middle parts, an end and a base. Each part is 5 inches long to make it easier to print and measure. Parts are fully compatible with my Lightsaber Creation Kit. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1274707

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 Microns

20%

Notes: I had to use supports on two pieces and I use rafts when I use massive supports. Everything else printed fine with no support.

Add a coupler to each end of the Barrel piece and then screw the pummel to the grip, the grip to the barrel, and the barrel into the emitter.  Plug the emitter ring into place and glue, same with the front and back buttons.  Plug the switch into the socket hole on the switch box and glue to the emitter head.  Plug the posts of the pummel studs into the pummel glueing them in place.  I actually used Acetone for glue as I printed in ABS.
If you want to paint it, test fit connect everything then disassemble to paint.  Also when screwing the parts together, they can sometimes be difficult to start the first time, but are easier after that.
This was modeled completely in Fusion 360.

This is a rocket that is designed to use a estats F50-6 rocket motor (29mm diameter, 98mm length), but can be powered with a homemade sugar rocket engine. Also if you have any suggestions please let me know in the comments.

Notes: Print all the parts straight up and down especially the nose cone.

Once the prints are done take a craft knife and remove all the supports. Then grab a piece of sandpaper and smooth everything down, the smoother everything is the higher it will fly. Grab a hot glue gun and a launch rod, add a little hot glue to the smaller ring of the rocket upper body and push it into the lower body of the rocket and line up the two pieces by inserting the launch rod into the launch lug, let it cool for 5 to 10 minutes. Next add a parachutes (www.youtube.com/watch?v=CISZ7RUye5w) by tying an elastic cord to the inside of the upper body and to the ring in the nose cone.

I used open Rockets to design the shape and size of the rocket to get a maximum altitude.  I than opened openScad to get the shape of the nose cone and exported it as a .obj file.  finally i went into Autodesk fusion 360 and fully designed the entire rocket.

description.text: Digital Hand

This is an Offworld M2019 Blaster stand. The gun itself is a desired collectible among Blade Runner fans as it represents a very accurate representation of the iconic movie pistol.  
The original M2019 usually comes with a plastic grip frame, plastic trigger guard and plastic pommel. It's nice in its original form. But a lot of people augment their pistol replica with a die-cast frame set that replaces these three plastic parts with die-cast metal, with the pommel being an amazingly shiny piece. It adds to the weight and realism of the replica.  
What I have created is a display base that would make any Blade Runner fan proud. It's a block of Ennis tiles, the tiles that make up Rick Deckard's apartment which was filmed in the famed Frank Lloyd Wright Ennis House. In fact, I downloaded the Ennis tile itself from Thingiverse and adapted it to create my block.  
Each block snaps into a base connector, which has a dovetail for the pistol grip base itself, forming a solid display base. The tiles have a slot and a groove on each corner to fit them together. The top tile sits in place without connectors, but will need gluing.  
There are two pommel stand files. One for the original plastic pommel that comes with the M2019, and one for the improved die-cast pommel you can purchase online.  
I hope you like it.  
I have not tested this on other replicas, and there are several different versions available. Feel free to adapt it to your own needs, but do not make it available commercially without talking to me. This uses an Ennis tile found here on Thingiverse, with the Share Alike licensing, but I would hope the original modeler gets some credit if you sell it. The pyramid on the base connector is my own printing logo (a 3D H for Huxter.)

To print this, print 3 of the side tiles (with "x3" in the filename), and one of the top and rear. Print one connector and your choice of pommel stands. (The plastic original or the die-cast upgrade.)  
The base and sides should slot into place very solidly, as should the pommel base. The top sits in the bevelled rim formed by the four tiles. There is no fancy snap connector for the top at the moment. I may add that later.  
I use a clear binary epoxy cement to glue it all together and it makes a very nice display stand.   
Print in whatever color you think complements your blaster. I like white. Gray may also be nice. Black would probably overpower the blaster itself.

author: teneopreto

description.text:
It's a big seven segment display :) I used three 5mm red/orange LEDs per segment with the intent that they could be wired in series and driven straight from a micro-controller output pin. Connecting my orange LED's wired up that way to a 5V supply gave a reading of 13 mA. A micro-controller should have no trouble driving the three leds without any transistors or resistors or anything. Depending on the voltage drop of your LED's you may need a small current limiting resistor. Other colors like green and blue will likely need to be wired in parallel with current limiting resistors due to the higher voltage drop of those LED's. 
I'd like to do a clock with this sometime soon. So I'll have to add an additional front plate with a clock type display instead of a decimal point. 
Eventually I'll try for an 8 inch display using interlocking segments. Once the prusa is running I could do an 8 inch display all in one print. Of course the ultimate goal is a 12 inch display like evil mad scientist labs has for $50 each. Then world domination. (cue maniacal laughter)

• Print the segments (7 of them ;) ) This would be a natural for translucent PLA but I just used natural ABS and it shines through nicely.
  • Print the decimal point
  • Print the display front plate. This is a full size print on the makerbot so if you are printing in ABS you might need to turn up your HBP.
  • Clean up the prints and test fit. Sand or trim squashed first layer etc. till they fit nice. Glue together if desired.
  • Drill out the segment membrane so the LED's will fit in.
  • Stick the LED's in the segments
  • Wire it up
  • Impress your friends with the size of your, um, display ;)

comments.author: gerty

comments.text: First picture and a word of advice that will seem very elementary to most: if using an Arduino to drive them, don't wire the LEDs in series, unless you have enough pins to drive them each from the 9V power (as I go back to read more about transistors). Apparently 5V is too weak for 3 LEDs in series - so I'm going to make a new version with them in parallel after checking current draw of my LEDs.  Looks awesome when testing out via that 9V supply though... more pics to come.
comments.author: gerty

comments.text: It depends a bit on what LED's you use. Color especially makes a difference in the voltage drop. So for some LED's you might not get much out of them at 5V in series but some may be OK or a bit dimmer than rated. Some may even need a small resistor to limit current. The main thing is don't exceed the 20mA rated for the pin on the arduino. The orange/red ones I have work fine wired in series at 5V with the current draw as stated in the original description. 13mA is not likely the optimal current (usually 15-20 mA)  to get full brightness but it works. Of course if you want full brightness you can always wire them in parallel with the appropriate resistors.
comments.author: gerty

comments.text: I made two side by side and colored the internal edges of the individual segments on one green (to counteract the red LEDs) with a sharpie and left the other one white. title: Simple wall pocket for hanging pens, and other small tools

description.text:
This is just a basic Wall hanging pocket to organize small tools for use around a desk or even a 3d Printer - nothing fancy.  
The sides have cutouts to allow visible access into the pockets.  I'm sure everyone has dropped a small part into these and forgotten about it because it was out of sight and mind.  
All corners are rounded to add printing strain relief.  
The base has a non-flat surface to reduce platen contact surface area and thus reduce the pain of removing the finished item.  
Hope someone finds this useful besides myself.

description.text: Wielu z Was robi filmy "z ręki", a ile przy tym trzeba wykazać cierpliwości i umiejętności w zachowaniu równowagi. Oczywiście i tak w rezultacie otrzymamy obraz, któremu czasami daleko do ideału. Rozwiązaniem jest oczywiście stabilizator, no tak, "ale to nie są tanie rzeczy" jak mawia mój brat. Kilka tysięcy, no może tysiąc z kawałkiem trochę szkoda wydawać, gdy już wydaliśmy na inny sprzet fotograficzny lub latający. Właśnie dzięki zapędowi w budowie copterów postanowiłem, zdjąć z jednego z nich gimbal 2-osiowy, doprojektować uchwyt z pojemnikiem na baterię i wykonać przenośny stabilizator obrazu. Jakie było moje miłe zaskoczenie, gdy podczas filmowania mogłem "płynąc z ujęciem" bez poruszeń lub wstrząsów. Uchwyt wydrukowałem na drukarce HARBOT z filamentu PLA Wolfix. Zapraszam do obejrzenia zdjęć wykonanego urządzenia.

This is my first excursion into blender.  My girlfriend cut her thumb pretty bad, and we wanted to keep her from using/bending it.  So I made this mold that goes under the thumb and will be held in place by the bandage.  
The side towards your hand is rounded downwards to be comfortable when you move your thumb around.  The little extrusions on the underside are to prevent thin bandage strips from sliding off (sometimes she leaves the wound open and only attaches two thin strips, instead of covering the whole thing with one huge bandage)  
Also, you might consider compressing it slightly in the Z-direction.  If you have skinny fingers, it may be too wide for you, but should still work fine at 70-90% width.

I have never used Blender before -- all I did was watch the first 11 minutes of this video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y__uzGKmxt8 and I was able to hack my way through it using the "a" and "b" keys, and dragging vertices around. Took me about an hour.

Not quite ready for the spotlight, this tray has been uploaded to share for a collaboration. It's intended to secure 5 Eppendorf tubes for a liquid nitrogen bath. The tray can then be transferred to a freezer or dry ice. Trays can be connected for shipping.
The trays can be secured top-to-bottom by threading onto a 1/4"-20 carriage bolt and then fastening the other end with a fender washer across the top of the sample tubes, followed by a spring or split washer, then a wingnut. Pictures and better instructions when I'm done, promise.
Future changes: A generic version without embedded labels. A printed pentagonal washer and spacers. Less material, more efficient layout, and better venting for LN2.

title: Small License Plate Vanity Edge Covers

description.text:
Wanted to be able to add some edge artwork (Advertisement) to my license plate but my printer will not print large enough to border the entire standard automobile license plate.  So, made these to bolt into one mount hole with a notched base to hook on the edge of the plate so that it will not rotate from position.  
Since the base is uneven, printing with support material of some kind is required.  Since that face is hidden, the support material doesn't need to be too dense.  With Repetier set for a 5mm support spacing and it works fine.

title: Dual nozzle modified for the Vulcanus V1

description.text:
Modified to work with the mounting of the belts of a Vulcanus v1.
Only thing i need now is to make a good platformcooling with a radial fan (same fan that Ultimaker uses to cool its electronic), but because im only printing in PLA this is not a big prio right now. The hotend I use that fits is a E3Dv6 clone with PTFE lining (aka more like a E3D V6 Lite) that fits very tightly.
http://www.aliexpress.com/item/E3D-V6-HotEnd-Full-Kit-1-75mm-12V-Bowden-for-RepRap-3D-Printer-Extruder/32320945428.html?spm=2114.13010208.99999999.267.3HoYCr Further more im also thinking about making the x-carrier with only 3 bearings not 4 as it is now. Im using the current one with only 3 bearings (one bearing between the two holders) at the moment and that seems to work best for me.

comments.text: The problem with a lot of Igus bushes (such as the one in this picture https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:91389) is that they are oversize because they are designed to be press-fit into a highly toleranced hole. This compresses the inner diameter down to the correct size. I understand that cable ties on these bushes will deform them somewhat and are not recommended.The bushes/bearings that are made of steel (or steel jackets) are perfectly fine to be used with the cable ties that this design is meant for.

Maybe I'll just have to buy the steel covered ones. The biggest problem for me right now is not deformation, because the ones I have are so cheap, that even if they deform a little I can get new ones, but rather that if they're slightly misaligned, they move really badly. Bridging due to the centrifugal (radial) fans

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

Post with links at http://eclecti.cc/computergraphics/augmented-reality-for-3d-printing My roommateâ€™s struggles designing his first 3D printed part gave me the idea to write an augmented reality viewer that lets you preview and interact with STL models in the real world without having to commit an object to plastic. This is actually sort of an update on part of a project I did for a Computational Photography course three years ago, but not terrible looking this time. I used the ArUco library to track the fiducial markers, largely because there is a javascript version if I ever want to make it web based. The program, which I uncreatively named arstl, reads in ASCII and binary STL files and displays them on top of the tracked marker. Right now, it uses a pretty basic OpenGL shader for a shiny plastic look, but I plan on making a more convincingly plastic one with bump mapping and subsurface scattering soon. As usual, the code is up on github under an ISC License. The STL parsing part of it is in the public domain, in case anyone finds it useful. Video of it in action at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HWSvJXuuznk
Source and README at: https://github.com/nrpatel/arstl

title: Indexed Concentric Rings, Dual Extruder Offset Calibration

description.text:
This is a remix of the Concentric Ring Extruder Offset Calibration object. I enlarged it slightly and added an index marker so the print can be removed from the bed without losing its orientation. The index mark should point toward the <Xmin,Ymin> corner.
After loading the two parts, assign each to a different extruder, then CENTER both parts on the bed to create the merged object. The inner ring should fit perfectly within the outer ring. After slicing and printing, measure any misalignment and adjust offsets accordingly. In most cases you'll want to apply HALF of the adjustment to each extruder.

author: itsetai

description.text:
This is my submission to the New Museum MakerBot Challenge. I created a small pyramid-shaped tool that slides onto the handle of most average toothbrushes. It has several parts that are replaceable to allow for color customization options.
The BrushNub functions as a platform to elevate the toothbrush off of the surface it is resting on, limiting the transfer of bacteria.
Additionally, the BrushNub has a hole routed through one side. When this hole is held under running water, gravity will force water through the hole and out in an arc, much like a water fountain. This arc of water is much easier to drink from.
I feel that this design successfully addresses two issues in an aesthetically pleasing, efficient, and customizable package. The BrushNub follows many aspects of good design: it is simple and easy to understand; there are no unnecessary parts (each part serves a distinct purpose); it is as little design as possible. This design is a derivative of the Brush and Rinse toothbrush and the Japanese toothpick. The Brush and Rinse allows water to be redirected in a similar fashion, but requires the consumer to replace their existing toothbrush; the BrushNub avoids this by fitting an existing toothbrush. The head of the Japanese toothpick can be snapped off and used as a resting platform to avoid transmitting bacteria; the BrushNub elevates the toothbrush for the same purpose.

My cleaner has a habit of switching everything off when she is done on a Friday afternoon.  The other weekend, as I was away until Monday, she decided to switch off the freezer! Monday found a freezer full of ruined (and quite smelly) food.  
To stop this from happening again, I made this to physically stop her from switching off anything important (like my home server!).  
This will fit a British 3 pin plug and I have included a right and left hand cover.  
No more cleaner related mishaps (hopefully).

I printed mine without any support.  There should be enough space between the cover and the switch to accommodate any saggy filament.  
Obviously, if you're really bothered about that sort of thing, you can always use support.  I'm not the boss of you!

remixed_from.author: MSollack
remixed_from.title: Threadless Ball Screw. No More Backlash

title: The new concept of X-end using by threadless ball screw system.

description.text:
The threadless ball screw system which was introduced by Mark Sollack is very useful concept on RepRap's z-axis structure.
Normally, the RepRap has two rod on the each side of Z-axis, the one is smooth rod and the other is threaded rod.
But it need just one rod on each side when the threadless ball screw system implemented.
It makes possible to guide and move the x-ends simultaneously with just one smooth rod at the each side of z-axis.
I think the threadless ball screw system can make the RepRap structure so simple. I designed the X-end motor holder and the 4.55 deg angle threadless ball screw nut for 2 mm lead length. But it's not tested yet. 20140104 - Added the XZ-idler.

This assembly need following parts.
  • x-end motor holder (at this post)
  • Threadless ball screw nut (at this post)
  • Oillesss bush holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:128060
  • Motor coupling http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:126992 (changeable)
  • Oilless bush (081215) -- 1EA
  • 623zz ball bearing -- 3EA
  • M3x5 dish head bolts -- 4EA
  • M3x10 bolts -- 11 EA
  • M3x17 or M3x20 bolts -- 2 EA
  • M3 Nuts -- 13 EA
  • M3 washer -- 3EA

comments.text: Sad to see this being build on the specs of a generation old printer.  Doesn't look like it's following the Mendel90 or i3's design, and I'm worried to see this thing be another triangle-frame with the same X axis rigidity problems as before.
comments.author: thantik

comments.text: Not necessarily; RepRap Version III (huxley) keeps the triangle frame.
I'm so sorry. It's for my printer Kid Mendel. Could I have a question what is the X axis rigidity problems?

The top vertices of the two triangles that make up the frame can wobble to the side, along the X axis. This causes horrible print problems, as far as I understand. My first printer was a Mendel90, so I never experienced X wobble.
comments.author: jspark

comments.text: Oh, I see, Thanks for your comment. I'll keep in mind. That's right, it would be possible to wobble along the x-axis on the old fashion frame. I've just checked out my printer by hand, I felt the wobbling was there. I should try to solve the problem. Thanks! :)
comments.author: Dekker3D

comments.text: Crossbars seem like the simplest solution, but that might get in the way of things. Maybe reinforce the top vertices?
comments.author: jspark

comments.text: Thanks Dekker3D! It's a very helpful comment. Please continuously check out my designs to prevent go ahead to the wrong way. :)
comments.author: Dekker3D

comments.text:
Good work jspark!
@thantik: this could easily be adapted to work on i3 or Mendel90.
Regarding frame bracing, I did this 18 months ago: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17123http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
And there are plenty of other frame braces. Stiffening up the vertices doesn't do it, because it's the rods flexing that causes the problem.

title: FTC ZTE Phone Mount for Xbox Controller 1.6

description.text:
This thing is still a Work in Progress. Files, instructions, and other stuff might change! This is a mount that connects a ZTE Speed Phone (probably works for others) to a Logitech F310 gamepad (probably works for others). It has spaces for wires to be wrapped around and a Monoprice 4-Port USB 2.0 HUB to be fitted into place. This was made for the FTC 2016 competition, but can be used for other purposes. It is in two separate parts that are attached by 2 knuts and bolts. I have attached a .dwg file for changes. Please comment below to tell me what did and didn't work. Thanks for reading Changelog:
1- 1.5
Lengthened some things and shortened others.
Added clips to hold hub better. 1.6
Lengthened back controller clip for better fitting.
Added clip at bottom of phone case to keep from falling.
Took off one clip of hub as having two clips made insertion impossible.
Strengthened corners due to weight of phone.
Added clips near phone for excess wire. 1.7
Added another hole for screws for stability reasons.

This is a 3D model of the WS2812B "NeoPixel" indexable 5050 RGB LED from Adafruit. You can view the product page at Adafruit here (https://www.adafruit.com/products/1655). I've begun dabbling in PCB design and needed to create a schematic and footprint for this little component so I could add it to my EDA software. As part of the PCB footprint, my EDA software allows me to attach a 3D model so the PCB can be rendered in 3D. Pretty nifty feature so I created this model to provide that. I've included the original AutoDesk Inventor part file, the exported STL file and the final WRL file that I generated and modified from the STL to add to my EDA software (I added colors which were wiped out in the STL export). I've attached a sample PCB design image showing the results in the EDA software. This model is more intended for 3D modeling than 3D printing - as a tool to design other objects that may interact with the LED or for use in other software like EDA tools.
A model of Graphene I made for a school project. I am not able to print this yet so i would not know how well it prints.

title: Space-efficient  Probe-Ready 25mm Dual Fan Shroud (for E3D-V6 CLONE - differs slightly in dimmensions from original)

description.text:
UPDATE 03/02/2016: More of an FYI: the clone I have is slightly different from a genuine E3D-V6. I mostly posted this design for the idea. With DesignSpark Mechanical (the free tool I use), I became productive in under a day and could modify STLs.
I wish I had an E3D-V6 so I can design parts for it or at least have enough time to make it parametric but for now this is all I can do:)
UPDATE 02/02/2016: Added a 12mm probe variant, as I couldn't find a capacitive probe (for non-metallic beds) smaller in diameter. As Inductive probes can be found for good prices from 6mm up, capacitive seem to come in two or three sizes, the smallest being 12mm. As you can see from the dimensioning picture, the distance to the nozzles is the same as with the 8mm version. Anyway I haven't seen a design that brings the probe this close to the nozzles.
Similar to my other Thing, the straight Dual 25mm Fan Shroud, this one makes it easy to accommodate an 8mm Inductive Proximity Probe without sacrificing too much space. Larger Probes can be accommodated but the distance from the nozzles would increase.
This should come together with a probe clamping part that you can design around it. I have included in the images a variation that I am developing for my Inductive Probe-based Dual Bowden Hotend Printer Head (The Corinthian).
The probe is at a minimum distance to the nozzles and i have included some dimensioning details. The ALU heater blocks should be angled as not to affect the probe with the emanated heat.
I will release the Corinthian Printer Head with more details when it will be ready.
NOTE that I haven't printed this part yet so I don't exactly know how it behaves but feel free to do it before me and post suggestions/improvements (I am including both STL and RSDOC -DesignSpark Mechanical- files).
Like my other shroud, this too should be installed by heating it with a hair dryer and snapping in place one hotend at a time.
